Terms.Name: Calendar
Terms.Description: Calendar defines the non-working days which affect the dates of contract events (CDE's) in combination with EOMC and BDC.

Terms.Name: BusinessDayConvention
Terms.Description:
BDC's are linked to a calendar. Calendars have working and non-working days. A BDC value other than N means that cash flows cannot fall on non-working days, they must be shifted to the next business day (following) or the previous on (preceding).
These two simple rules get refined twofold:
- Following modified (preceding): Same like following (preceding), however if a cash flow gets shifted into a new month, then  it is shifted to preceding (following) business day.
- Shift/calculate (SC) and calculate/shift (CS). Accrual, principal, and possibly other calculations are affected by this choice. In the case of SC first the dates are shifted and after the shift cash flows are calculated. In the case of CS it is the other way round.
Attention: Does not affect non-cyclical dates such as PRD, MD, TD, IPCED since they can be set to the correct date directly.

Terms.Name: EndOfMonthConvention
Terms.Description:
When computing schedules a special problem arises if an anchor date is at the end of a month and a cycle of monthly or quarterly is applied (yearly in the case of leap years only). How do we have to interpret an anchor date April 30 plus 1M cycles? In case where EOM is selected, it will jump to the 31st of May, then June 30, July 31 and so on. If SM is selected, it will jump to the 30st always with of course an exception in February. 
This logic applies for all months having 30 or less days and an anchor date at the last day. Month with 31 days will at any rate jump to the last of the month if anchor date is on the last day.

Terms.Name: ContractType
Terms.Description: The ContractType is the most important information. It defines the cash flow generating pattern of a contract. The ContractType information in combination with a given state of the risk factors will produce a deterministic sequence of cash flows which are the basis of any financial analysis.

Terms.Name: StatusDate
Terms.Description: SD holds the date per which all attributes of the record were updated. This is especially important for the highly dynamic attributes like Accruals, Notional, interest rates in variable instruments etc.

Terms.Name: ContractRole
Terms.Description:
CNTRL defines which position the LEIRC ( the creator of the contract record ) takes in a contract. For example, whether the contract is an asset or liability, a long or short position for the LEIRC. 
Most contracts are simple on or off balance sheet positions which are assets, liabilities. Such contracts can also play a secondary role as a collateral. 
The attribute is highly significant since it determines the direction of all cash flows. The exact meaning is given with each CT in the ACTUS High Level Specification document.

Terms.Name: LegalEntityIDRecordCreator
Terms.Description:
This identifies the legal entity creating the contract record. The counterparty of the contract is tracked in LEICP.
LEIRC is ideally the official LEI which can be a firm, a government body, even a single person etc. However, this can also refer to a annonymous group in which case this information is not to be disclosed. LEIRC may also refer to a group taking a joint risk.

Terms.Name: ContractID
Terms.Description:
Unique identifier of a contract.  
If the system is used on a single firm level, an internal unique ID can be generated. If used on a national or globally level, a globally unique ID is required.

Terms.Name: LegalEntityIDCounterparty
Terms.Description:
LEICP identifies the counterparty to the LEIRC in this contract.
LEICP is ideally the official LEI which can be a firm, a government body, even a single person etc. However, this can also refer to a annonymous group in which case this information is not to be disclosed. LEICP may also refer to a group taking a joint risk or more generally, LEICP is the main counterparty, against which the contract has been settled.

Terms.Name: ContractStatus
Terms.Description: Indicates the current contract performance status. Different states of the contract range from performing to default.

Terms.Name: Seniority
Terms.Description: Refers to the order of repayment in the event of a sale or default of the issuer.

Terms.Name: NonPerformingDate
Terms.Description: The date at which the ContractStatus changed to DF (=Default).

Terms.Name: PrepaymentPeriod
Terms.Description: If real payment happens before scheduled payment date minus PPP, then it is considered a prepayment. Effect of prepayments are further described in PPEF and related fields.

Terms.Name: GracePeriod
Terms.Description: If real payment happens after scheduled payment date plus GRP, then the payment is in delay.

Terms.Name: DelinquencyPeriod
Terms.Description: If real payment happens after scheduled payment date plus DLP, then the counterparty is in technical default. This means that the creditor legally has the right to declare default of the debtor.

Terms.Name: DelinquencyRate
Terms.Description: Rate at which Delinquency Payments accrue on NT (in addition to the interest rate) during the DelinquencyPeriod

Terms.Name: CycleAnchorDateOfFee
Terms.Description: Date from which the fee payment date schedule is calculated according to the cycle length. The first fee payment event takes place on this anchor.

Terms.Name: CycleOfFee
Terms.Description: Defines in combination with FEANX the payment points of fees

Terms.Name: FeeBasis
Terms.Description: Basis, on which Fee is calculated. For FEB=’A’, FER is interpreted as an absolute amount to be paid at every FP event and for FEB=’N’, FER represents a rate at which FP amounts accrue on the basis of the contract’s NT.

Terms.Name: FeeRate
Terms.Description: Rate of Fee which is a percentage of the underlying or FER is an absolute amount. For all contracts where FEB does not apply (cf. business rules), FER is interpreted as an absolute amount.

Terms.Name: FeeAccrued
Terms.Description: Accrued fees as per SD

Terms.Name: ArrayCycleAnchorDateOfInterestPayment
Terms.Description: Same like IPANX but as array

Terms.Name: ArrayCycleOfInterestPayment
Terms.Description: Same like IPCL but as array

Terms.Name: NominalInterestRate
Terms.Description:
The nominal interest rate which will be used to calculate accruals and the next interest payment at the next IP date. NT multiplied with IPNR is the base for the interest payment calculation. The relevant time period is a function of IPDC. 
If the contract is variable (RRANX set) this field is periodically updated per SD. 
In the case of plan vanilla interest rate swaps (IRSPV) this defines the rate of fixed leg.

Terms.Name: DayCountConvention
Terms.Description: Method defining how days are counted between two dates. This finally defines the year fraction in accrual calculations.

Terms.Name: AccruedInterest
Terms.Description: Accrued interest as per SD. In case of NULL, this value will be recalculated using IPANX, IPCL and IPNR information. Can be used to represent irregular next IP payments.

Terms.Name: CapitalizationEndDate
Terms.Description: If IPCED is set, then interest is not paid or received but added to the balance (NT) until IPCED. If IPCED does not coincide with an IP cycle, one additional interest payment gets calculated at IPCED and capitalized. Thereafter normal interest payments occur.

Terms.Name: CycleAnchorDateOfInterestCalculationBase
Terms.Description: Date from which the interest calculation base date schedule is calculated according to the cycle length. The first interest calculation base event takes place on this anchor.

Terms.Name: CycleOfInterestCalculationBase
Terms.Description:
Concerning the format see PRCL. 
Defines the subsequent adjustment points to NT of the interest payment calculation base.

Terms.Name: InterestCalculationBase
Terms.Description:
This is important for amortizing instruments. The basis of interest calculation is normally the notional outstanding amount as per SD. This is considered the fair basis and in many countries the only legal basis. If NULL or NTSD is selected, this is the case. 
Alternative bases (normally in order to favor the lending institution) are found. In the extreme case the original balance (PCDD=NT+PDCDD) never gets adjusted. In this case PCDD must be chosen. 
An intermediate case exist wherre balances do get adjusted, however with lags. In this case NTL mut be selected and anchor dates and cycles must be set.

Terms.Name: InterestCalculationBaseAmount
Terms.Description: This is the amount used for the calculation of interest. Calculation base per SD.

Terms.Name: Currency
Terms.Description: The currency of the cash flows.

Terms.Name: AmortizationDate
Terms.Description: This Date is used to calculate the annuity amounts for ANN and ANX NGX CT's. Needs only to be set in case where the contract balloon at MD and MD is less than AD.

Terms.Name: ContractDealDate
Terms.Description: This date signifies the origination of the contract where an agreement between the customer and the bank has been settled. From this date on, the institution will have a (market) risk position for financial contracts. This is even the case when IED is in future.

Terms.Name: InitialExchangeDate
Terms.Description: Date of the initial cash flow for Maturity and Non-Maturity CT's. It also coincides with the beginning of interest accrual calculation.

Terms.Name: PremiumDiscountAtIED
Terms.Description:
Total original premium or discount that has been set at CDD and will be added to the (notional) cash flow at IED (cash flow at IED = NT+PDIED, w.r.t. an RPA CT). 
Negative value for discount and positive for premium.
Note, similar to interest the PDIED portion is part of P&L.

Terms.Name: MaturityDate
Terms.Description:
Marks the contractual end of the lifecycle of a CT. Generally, date of the last cash flows. 
This includes normally a principal and an interest payment. Some Maturity CTs as perpetuals (PBN) do not have such a date. For variable amortizing contracts of the ANN CT, this date might be less than the scheduled end of the contract (which is deduced from the periodic payment amount 
PRNXT). In this case it balloons.

Terms.Name: NotionalPrincipal
Terms.Description:
Total remaining outstanding principal as per SD. Hence, for amortizing instruments NT will be updated per SD in order to represent current outstanding principal. 
Although initial NT will be defined at CDD it will only flow at IED or PRD. The first Cash Flow at IED or PRD is equal to NT+PDIED.
NT is generally the basis on which interest payments are calculated. If IPCBS is set, IPCBS may introduce a different basis for interest payment calculation.

Terms.Name: ArrayCycleAnchorDateOfPrincipalRedemption
Terms.Description: Same like PRANX but as array

Terms.Name: ArrayCycleOfPrincipalRedemption
Terms.Description: Same like PRCL but as array

Terms.Name: ArrayNextPrincipalRedemptionPayment
Terms.Description: Same like PRNXT but as array

Terms.Name: PurchaseDate
Terms.Description:
If a contract is bought after initiation (for example a bond on the secondary market) this date has to be set. It refers to the date at which the payment (of PPRD) and transfer of the security happens. In other words, PRD - if set - takes the role otherwise IED has from a cash flow perspective. 
Note, LEICP of the CT is not the counterparty of the transaction!

Terms.Name: PriceAtPurchaseDate
Terms.Description:
Purchase price exchanged at PRD.  
PPRD represents a “clean” price (includes premium/discount but not IPAC).

Terms.Name: TerminationDate
Terms.Description:
If a contract is sold before MD (for example a bond on the secondary market) this date has to be set. It refers to the date at which the payment (of PTD) and transfer of the security happens. In other words, TD - if set - takes the role otherwise MD has from a cash flow perspective. 
Note, LEICP of the CT is not the counterparty of the transaction!

Terms.Name: PriceAtTerminationDate
Terms.Description: Sellingprice exchanged at PTD  PTDrepresents a “clean” price (includes premium/discount but not IPAC

Terms.Name: CycleAnchorDateOfScalingIndex
Terms.Description: Date from which the scaling date schedule is calculated according to the cycle length. The first scaling event takes place on this anchor.

Terms.Name: CycleOfScalingIndex
Terms.Description:
Cycle according to which the scaling date schedule will be calculated.
In case SCCL is not set, then there will only be one scaling event at SCANX given SCANX is set.
The interval will be adjusted yet by EOMC and BDC.

Terms.Name: ScalingEffect
Terms.Description: Indicates which payments are scaled. I = Interest payments, N = Nominal payments and M = Maximum deferred interest amount. They can be scaled in any combination.

Terms.Name: MarketValueObserved
Terms.Description: Value as observed in the market at SD per unit. Incase of fixed income instruments it is a fraction.

Terms.Name: OptionExerciseEndDate
Terms.Description: Final exercise date for American and Bermudan options, expiry date for European options.

Terms.Name: CycleAnchorDateOfOptionality
Terms.Description:
Used for Basic Maturities (such as PAM, RGM, ANN, NGM and their Step-up versions) and American and Bermudan style options. 
- Basic Maturities: Within the group of these Maturities, it indicates the possibility of prepayments. Prepayment features are controlled by Behavior. 
- American and Bermudan style Options: Begin of exercise period.

Terms.Name: CycleOfOptionality
Terms.Description:
Cycle according to which the option execution date schedule will be calculated.
OPCL can be NULL for American Options or Prepayment Optionality in which case the optionality period starts at OPANX and ends at OPXED (for american options) or MD (in case of prepayment optionality).
The interval will be adjusted yet by EOMC and BDC.

Terms.Name: PenaltyType
Terms.Description: Defines whether prepayment is linked to a penalty and of which kind.

Terms.Name: PenaltyRate
Terms.Description: Either the rate or the absolute amount of the prepayment.

Terms.Name: PrepaymentEffect
Terms.Description: This attribute defines whether or not the right of prepayment exists and if yes, how prepayment affects the remaining principal redemption schedule of the contract

Terms.Name: ArrayCycleAnchorDateOfRateReset
Terms.Description: Same like RRANX but as array

Terms.Name: ArrayCycleOfRateReset
Terms.Description: Same like RRCL but as array

Terms.Name: ArrayRate
Terms.Description: For array-type rate reset schedules, this attribute represents either an interest rate (corresponding to IPNR) or a spread (corresponding to RRSP). Which case applies depends on the attribute ARFIXVAR: if ARFIXVAR=”FIX” then it represents the new IPNR and if ARFIXVAR=”VAR” then the applicable RRSP.

Terms.Name: ArrayFixedVariable
Terms.Description: For array-type rate reset schedules, this attributes defines the meaning of ARRATE.

Terms.Name: MarketObjectCodeOfRateReset
Terms.Description:
Is pointing to the interest rate driver (MarketObject) used for rate reset uniquely.
Unique codes for market objects must be used.

Terms.Name: LifeCap
Terms.Description:
For variable rate basic CTs this represents a cap on the interest rate that applies during the entire lifetime of the contract.
For CAPFL CTs this represents the cap strike rate.

Terms.Name: LifeFloor
Terms.Description:
For variable rate basic CTs this represents a floor on the interest rate that applies during the entire lifetime of the contract.
For CAPFL CTs this represents the floor strike rate.

Terms.Name: PeriodCap
Terms.Description: For variable rate basic CTs this represents the maximum positive rate change per rate reset cycle.

Terms.Name: PeriodFloor
Terms.Description: For variable rate basic CTs this represents the maximum negative rate change per rate reset cycle.

Terms.Name: FixingDays
Terms.Description: Interest rate resets (adjustments) are usually fixed one or two days (usually Business Days) before the new rate applies (defined by the rate reset schedule). This field holds the period between fixing and application of a rate.

Terms.Name: NextResetRate
Terms.Description: Holds the new rate that has been fixed already (cf. attribute FixingDays) but not applied. This new rate will be applied at the next rate reset event (after SD and according to the rate reset schedule). Attention, RRNXT must be set to NULL after it is applied!

Terms.Name: RateMultiplier
Terms.Description:
Interest rate multiplier. A typical rate resetting rule is LIBOR plus x basis point where x represents the interest rate spread.
However, in some cases like reverse or super floater contracts an additional rate multiplier applies. In this case, the new rate is determined as: IPNR after rate reset = Rate selected from the market object * RRMLT + RRSP.
